Finally, considering counterfactual families also matters for migration policies. Many details of migration policy can instead affect decisions of whether and whom to marry, and policies might also want to help potential migrants visualize how their family might change if they migrate. 5/5

This also complicates efforts to run a regression like:
Spousal Labor = a + b*Your Migration + Controls  + e
Since even if you have an instrument for migration, the existence and identity of your spouse can change with location. We discuss some potential solutions to this in the post and paper. 4/n

It is really hard to visualize the potential spouse and kids (or lack thereof) that you are giving up by not moving to a particular location - which can bias people towards not moving. It can also make migration decisions locationally and dynamically inconsistent 3/n

While the literature typically models migration as a family decision, we show the family itself frequently changes with migration. Adult migrants to the U.S. are more likely to marry after migrating than before - and so different destinations entail meeting and marrying different spouses. 2/n

International migrants face very different wages in different home and away destinations. But they also may end up with very different families as well, in ways that are hard to visualize in advance. My latest blog post summarizes my new paper with Elie Murard and Simone Bertoli on this issue 1/n

Efforts to directly get jobseekers on online job platforms have typically not increased employment and occasionally backfires. But government can help make these platforms work better. E.g. trust is a big issue, so a role for background checks, reputation mechanisms; and skill certification.

we highlight several areas for policy action:
1) Helping workers search in new locations - including migration.
2) Helping jobseekers correct biased beliefs - challenge is making this new and credible.
3) Enabling jobseekers to better signal skills (e.g. thru testing, certification, references)

Surprisingly few surveys ask those with jobs how they found them (more ask the unemployed what they've done to look for jobs, but without knowing what succeeds). We show most jobs found through social networks & direct applying to employers: not through intermediation agencies or online platforms

The more successful efforts appear to teach jobseekers something more fundamental about themselves and their understanding of the labor market (e.g. by changing their beliefs or the labor markets they look in), or teach the market something about the jobseekers (e.g. by helping signal skills)
